Tony \"TJ\" Caruso Jr..Action: Picks up litter on the sidewalk and drops it in the trash can before going to work.
Insists on waiting at a busted red light despite being alone and the light clearly not working.
Shows awareness of parole rules and enforces boundaries strictly by confronting his father about unauthorized contact with someone in the department.
Demonstrates honesty and integrity by refusing to run the red light even though everybody else would.
Does not move or yield to a honking car despite being told to go.
Insists Big Tony eat a real breakfast and be punctual for his job interview, showing care and responsibility.
Uses an embarrassed tone correcting Big Tony about Gabby's name and status, indicating respect and sensitivity.
Fiddles with ball and strike counter and plans to umpire Evan's little league game, showing involvement in family activities.
Refuses a new TV gift without further discussion, showing possible bluntness or rejection.
Corrects Big Tony about the importance of punctuality for the job interview, emphasizing being early rather than approximate.
Shows awareness of his father's formal shirt needs and insists on a 'real shirt with a collar' for the interview, indicating preparation and seriousness.
Fiddles with the ball and strike counter for Evan's little league game, showing responsibility and multitasking.
Refuses new TV offered by Big Tony, possibly indicating practicality or rejection of unnecessary gifts.
Embarrassed calling Inspector Vasquez 'Gabby', showing some social awkwardness or discomfort.
Corrects rookie on infraction but remains professional
Shakes partner awake, offers coffee and expresses concern about his career
Jokes about partner's retirement in a light manner
Uses humor to relieve tension while arriving at the crime scene
Directs officers to take separate statements and separate cars for the dirt bikers to avoid collusion and contamination of statements.
Refuses to remove the trash bag from the victim's head until the medical examiner arrives, showing respect for proper procedure and the victim.
Exhibits focus and thoroughness while examining the victim and crime scene, but shows no empathy or emotional response in the excerpt.
Big Tony offers to get a receipt within twelve hours to cover up the missing proof of purchase.
Tells Donna to 'Save your tears' and says Jack was 'dead to you, to all of you' after agreeing to testify.
Quietly encourages his son Evan during the game, saying 'Good eye, buddy. Wait for your pitch.' and 'Good hit though. Way to hustle.'
Strictly enforces the rules by calling his son out for stepping out of the baseline despite boos from the crowd and players.
Quietly encourages Evan to have a good eye and wait for the right pitch.
Judges Evan out for being out of the baseline using the rules despite boos from parents and players.
Takes out the rule book to justify his call amid opposition.
Does not back down from applying the rules even though it makes him unpopular at the game.
Redirects team focus back to the job after distraction, encouraging order and productivity.
Recognizes that the case seems premeditated and suggests a logical lead by focusing on the wife as a suspect.
Immediately directs the team to check phone records, ensure DA involvement, verify alibis, and start clearing suspects efficiently.
Interrupts distracted banter about the high-tech watch to refocus the group on investigative priorities.
Unholsters and surrenders his weapon silently when asked without protest.
Looks stunned and anxious when confronted with the evidence but remains composed enough to observe the ballistics test himself.
Takes responsibility for his service weapon, keeps it with him 24-7, admits no lapses in security.
Provides clear, straightforward answers to Inspector Quinn about his whereabouts and sleeping arrangements.
Does not lock his nightstand drawer where his gun is kept, despite the importance of its security.
Gabby seeks honesty from Tony; despite pressure, Tony remains guarded and repeatedly says he doesn't know what happened.
Tony calls out for his father at home and makes efforts to find him by calling around, showing concern and responsibility.
Carries and tapes a bouquet of flowers at a makeshift memorial, sits with his father in shared grief, shows persistence in seeking justice for Connie.
Gently tries to change the subject/location for a serious conversation with his father, indicating sensitivity to the emotional weight of their surroundings.
Confronts his father with difficult truths about the investigation and implicates family involvement with a firm but cautious approach.
Confronts his father about the shooting and inconsistencies surrounding the case, showing determination and a sense of justice.
Reads Gunther Welles' rap sheet and refers to him derogatorily as 'this jerk', showing judgment and lack of tolerance.
Maintains a tense but respectful tone with his father despite conflict, demonstrating sincerity and familial loyalty.
Pays for food to support Big Tony despite being on a stakeout.
Invites Gabby to join their team and appreciates her input.
Engages in friendly chat with suspect, shares laughs and drinks at bar.
Acknowledges suspect as friend of his father and offers VIP treatment.
Warns bartender not to shoot, calls in backup after gunfight starts, tries to control situation despite being seriously wounded.
No sign of self-preservation by immediately calling for help and signaling code after being seriously shot.
Encourages Gunther to grab the gun and shoot, pushing him to act despite Gunther’s obvious fear and inexperience with firearms.
Reveals the staged nature of the gunfire and interacts with others lightheartedly about improv skills, showing camaraderie and a sense of humor.
Orchestrates a staged shooting scene to test Gunther's reaction and honesty, demonstrating creative problem-solving and control over a complex situation.
Calmly sits up unhurt after the staged gunshots, showing confidence and composure under pressure.
Studies the case board alone, methodically eliminates a suspect based on evidence, indicating analytical and investigative competence.
Considers Gabby warmly when their eyes meet, engaging in friendly banter.
Responds to Gabby’s provocation lightly, showing humor and tolerance.
Does not react negatively when Gabby mixes up his carefully organized desk; instead sighs and fixes it.
Keeps playing bossa nova music to help him think, showing a calm and composed demeanor.
Admits awareness he will have to testify without complaint or defensiveness.
Avoids discussing his childhood or family issues deeply and admits he never asked about them despite suspicion.
Maintains a carefully organized desk and reports, indicating a methodical approach.
Uses bossa nova music to help him think, showing self-awareness of his working style.
Acknowledges he has to testify and is aware of his situation, displaying acceptance and readiness.
Demurs wine offered to him to stay focused, demonstrating discipline.
Does not ask questions about his own background despite possible suspicions, indicating avoidance or lack of initiative.
Responds to Big Tony's worry with guarded but honest actions, including embracing and openly removing his shirt to prove he is not wired.
Shares a sincere exchange of love with Big Tony before parting for the night.
Defiantly removes his shirt and undershirt to prove he is not wired, confidently demonstrating honesty under suspicion.
Engages in guarded, suspicious interaction with Big Tony, showing awareness of potential distrust and maintaining composure.
Observes Sgt. Finch and Donna with suspicion; stealthily follows them upstairs and interrupts their private moment.
Observes Sgt. Finch interacting with Donna's dog and relatives, noting their familiarity.
Casually follows Donna and Sgt. Finch upstairs without attracting attention.
Interrupts Donna and Sgt. Finch during their private moment by opening the door and saying 'Knock knock.'
Shows concern for Sgt. Finch's well-being by noticing and commenting on his rash and suggesting it might be poison sumac.
Accuses Sgt. Finch of being involved in a murder without direct evidence, approaching him pointedly and suspiciously.
Eagerly shares his theory about the murder and asks Loomis to verify evidence, showing determination and trust in his own sense of justice.
Shows focus and control when Loomis tells him the case is over and his father confessed, shifting from excitement to processing the information.
Visits his father in prison, engaging in a personal, familial interaction despite the circumstances.
Points out the poison sumac rash on Sergeant Finch's leg and suggests it can be matched in the lab to prove involvement in the crime.
Accuses Sergeant Finch of killing Jack Livingston with his gun impulsively without clear evidence.
Gets excited about solving the case but is told the case is already closed and his father confessed, showing lack of control or premature conclusions.
Shows awareness and focus by finally asking 'What's over?' when told the case is closed.
Sits with Big Tony in prison, listens to his heartfelt expressions and tries to reason about the murder confession.
Tries to protect his father by asserting he didn't kill anybody and suggests alternative suspects to clear Big Tony.
Has a tender moment with his son Evan, encouraging him gently to try olives and calling his reluctance intelligence in a friendly manner.
Notices a pattern in the olives and rearranges them, leading to a sudden idea and referencing the case file.
Articulates a theory about the shooting, including a detailed reconstruction of events involving multiple suspects.
Rushes to get Gabby and insists on going home, showing urgency and confidence in his insight.
Is distracted and easily caught up in his thoughts but remains focused on solving the case.
Explains the crime method calmly and shares crucial information with Gabby.
Clarifies that he did not kill Livingston and expresses relief that the victim was already dead.
Annoys Gabby by interrupting when she jokes about his shooting pattern
Invites Gabby along and shares his plan about the investigation
Uses his knowledge and access to enter the police training facility after hours
Engages collaboratively with Gabby while searching for evidence
Displays confidence that his evidence will convince Gabby
Remembers and identifies a distinctive bullet hole pattern from a prior target with confidence.
Confidently leads and executes plan to access a police training facility by knowing and using the security code to enter after hours.
Finds and compares evidence (used paper targets) methodically, confirming a key match that supports his case.
Dismisses skepticism from Gabby with annoyance rather than constructive explanation.
Tells Gabby not to touch evidence to preserve the chain of evidence.
Shows concern for Gabby by asking if she seriously wants to take the exam and offers to talk to the Captain about hiring her.
Tells Sgt. Finch 'You don't want to do this, Chet. You're not a murderer.'
Huddles closely with Gabby for cover during a gunfight, expressing concern and cooperation.
Insists on taking the gun from Gabby, claiming to be a better shot.
Shoots Finch in the shoulder to stop him, kicks the gun away
Returns to crime scene of his mother's murder to study it obsessively
Embraces Big Tony warmly after his release, reassures him not to worry.
Patiently obeys an outdated stop sign despite urging from Big Tony to move on quickly.
Reluctantly holds up the situation by waiting despite pressure from another car and relative to proceed immediately.
Refuses to run the red light despite the streets being empty and the light being broken, choosing to wait honestly.
Strictly enforces parole conditions with his father, warning him not to have contact with department members.
Identifies a uniform infraction and calls it out professionally.
Responds appropriately and assertively to a partner who is asleep on the job, attempts to keep him alert and aware of consequences.
Demonstrates wit and confidence by teasing his partner while maintaining authority.
Walks up to a crime scene and immediately starts assessing and questioning the scene and witnesses.
Allows his partner to fall behind without objection and continues leading the investigation.
Sells his liquor license and moves in with his kid to follow instructions, committed to finding a job within the deadline.
Teases Gabby about a photo amiably.
Keeps a photo of his ex-partner, whom he hates, as a reminder to outlive him, indicating lingering bitterness.
Sells his liquor license without issue as requested.
Moves in with his kid promptly and cooperates with the imposed conditions.
Shows confidence in his ability to find a job within three weeks, demonstrating determination and a plan.
Uses a personal photo to remind himself of priorities and fuel motivation, indicating emotional intelligence and strategic thinking.
Despite pressure, maintains a degree of humor and rapport, which may reflect social competence though not directly related to problem-solving.
Exchanges tense, overly-polite greetings with Kayla after divorce.
Responds to Kayla's playful teasing with light sarcasm but stays engaged.
Shows professionalism and responsibility by prioritizing the investigation over personal plans.
Shares grim details of the victim’s death openly with Big Tony, showing trust and transparency.
Responds seriously to Big Tony’s dark humor and joins in good-natured banter.
Directly requests Big Tony’s help in investigation, signaling willingness to collaborate despite past tensions.
Refers to Donna as a 'people-pleaser' and acknowledges her likability.
Engages professionally with the team, asking for key details and focusing on the facts of the case.
Quickly summarizes autopsy results and probes for key information like time of death despite incomplete data.
Acknowledges large time window for time of death, showing realistic understanding of case limitations.
Focuses on salient facts only (time of death headlines), not bogged down in details.
Acknowledges the ballistic evidence openly and admits to running the test himself twice, demonstrating transparency and confidence in his own skills.
Rejects private conversation with union rep insisting all be present to figure out what happened, showing willingness to confront the situation openly.
Allows others to speak on his behalf about his clean record and reputation, indicating possible reliance on others rather than self-advocacy.
Recalls the exact issuance date of his weapon and claims continuous possession without loss.
Keeps the weapon in an unlocked drawer next to the bed, accessible while sleeping.
Provides a detailed alibi for the time frame of the murder, including exact times and activities.
Does not lock the drawer where the weapon is kept, potentially endangering chain of custody.
Acknowledges he cannot be completely certain the weapon was not taken while he was asleep, showing some awareness.
Maintains composure under departmental review and does not lash out when confronted by Gabby, indicating a level of professional self-control.
Pushes past Gabby to leave and meet someone despite the tension, showing decisiveness and focus.
Claims ignorance about the incident multiple times and offers no additional information or insight, indicating either lack of knowledge or unwillingness to problem-solve.
Calls around looking for his father and instructs others to have his father call him when found, showing initiative and concern, although limited in scope.
Carefully creates a makeshift memorial with flowers and tries to protect them by taping them to prevent blowing away.
Analyzes evidence such as the bank camera footage and uses it to keep the investigation going, showing persistence and understanding of investigative value.
Advises his father not to ask around because his father is a suspect, showing awareness of the risks and procedural caution.
Attempts to have a serious conversation with his father in a private setting rather than in public or at the memorial site, indicating thoughtful communication and emotional intelligence.
Confronts his father assertively about the shooting and the use of his gun, demonstrating careful reasoning about access and timelines.
Conducts a stakeout and researches Gunther Welles's criminal record to gather information.
Maintains composure despite being stunned by new information about Gunther being involved.
Engages in a tense conversation with Big Tony and sticks to the facts without escalating emotionally.
Does not immediately jump to conclusions about his father's guilt, showing measured judgment.
Remains patient and lets Big Tony explain the situation despite disagreeing about having food delivered on a stakeout.
Pays for the food when Big Tony asks, showing flexibility and pragmatic decision-making in a less-than-ideal situation.
Welcomes Gabby to the team and values her 'fresh set of eyes', showing openness and collaborative intelligence.
Quickly connects new suspect Gunther Welles to a previous suspect (Manny Corkrin) and relevant case details.
Acknowledges the evidence is thin but insists it is a connection worth pursuing, showing persistence and logical thinking.
Engages collaboratively with others to reconstruct the crime scenario using a floor plan and discussion, demonstrating resourcefulness and teamwork.
Relies heavily on a single piece of weak evidence (his own gun) and admits to lack of stronger proof, indicating some limitation in investigative ability or preparation.
Identifies a fundamental investigative rule: 'Murderers lie.'
Maintains a casual, friendly interview atmosphere at Dino's Bar with a suspect and his colleagues.
Offers the suspect VIP treatment due to a personal connection with the suspect’s father.
Immediately calls in a code 998 with precise location and situation details after gunfire starts.
Urgently shouts to stop the bartender from firing, suggesting awareness about escalation.
Is seriously wounded by gunfire during the shootout.
Despite being wounded, stays conscious and braces for the gangster’s attack as a last stand.
Shows up uninvited to a tense reception despite being unwelcome, tries to seem inconspicuous and polite, greets a family member with a friendly 'How you doing?'
Persists in attending despite others' clear hostility and exclusion (treated like a leper), indicating a willingness to face social discomfort
Ignores or does not address Donna's openly hostile attitude and the threatening dog, attempting to maintain composure

Arrives at a tense scene despite being warned to stay away; insists on showing up to maintain appearances.
Attempts to be inconspicuous and polite at a hostile reception among mourners.

Calls Gabby to get her support and help, showing trust and openness.
